text: well this may seem like a remote area
hundreds of miles away from the capital
but actually I'm less than an hour away
from Islamabad this is the hassan abdul
area and it's well known for caves like
these ones behind me not for historical
or archaeological reasons but because
people actually live inside these caves
they're man-made and for generations
families have come here and dug inside
those hills so we're going to go in and
see what it's like right the one thing
that you notice right away is the
remarkable difference in temperature
drops right down so it's actually quite
cool here and outside it felt quite bare
but inside it feels homely and cozy I
mean there are pots and pans and
decorations family pictures through
these tablecloths and little makeshift
beds and something that's not very cave
like is that electrical connection at
the entrance someone is charging their
phone and there is a light bulb for when
it gets really dark at night there are
also drawings on the walls so modern-day
cave drawings abdullah is our host he's
been living here with his family's
Angela yeah huh thank you so much for
speaking to us tell me how long you've
been living here in this cave
very surreal I've lived here for almost
50 years with my wife and children and
now my grandchildren live here too when
I first moved here this place was
completely empty the caves had already
been dug up but no one was here I was
very poor looking for work and had no
other option my children and I work the
land and do other our jobs in the
surrounding areas to make a living we
have this cave and the one next door but
it does get crowded with all of us here
I would love to have a home of my own
for me and my family but it's very
difficult I can't afford any but given
the chance yes I would you don't live in
these caves by choice
you said that you are forced to live
here because you can't afford housing
but is there anything you like about
living here
I said occasionally what can i see it's
sheltered roof or our heads that's all
